results.title: Proof (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Jocelyn Moorhouse, Lynda House and House and Moorhouse Films
results.brief_description: Winner of 7 Australian Film Institute awards, “Proof” is a provocative and engrossing film about a man’s obsessive search for truth. Martin (Hugo Weaving) has been blind from birth. He trusts no-one, except for the camera which has replaced his eyes. His photos are proof that the world he senses is the same as other people see. Then he meets a young kitchen hand, Andy, whose honesty and kindness allow Martin to trust for the first time - until Martin’s jealous housekeeper, Celia, sets out to destroy this relationship. Written and directed by Jocelyn Moorhouse who won a 1992 Victorian Premier’s Literary Award for her screenplay.

results.title: Promises, promises: small town survival
results.creator_credit: Reevan Dolgoy, Roger Hart and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A film exploring the problems and potential’s of small towns in the Drumheller Valley region of Alberta. It documents the citizen participation generated in the region by the Task Force on Urbanisation and the Future, the citizens’ reaction to curtailment of the Task Force exercise, the events that followed, and the lesson of this experience for other districts facing similar problems.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Reevan Dolgoy, Roger Hart and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Promises
results.creator_credit: B.Z. Goldberg, Justine Shapiro and Promises Film Project
results.brief_description: Promises was filmed over a period of four years, from 1997 to 2000, a time where there seemed to be a degree of relative calm in Israel and the Palestinian Territories (following on from the Oslo Accords). Perceiving the Israeli-Palestinian Conflict through the eyes of seven children, this film is an astoundingly compassionate and illuminating document about the human cost of war. Four of the children are Jewish and live in the city. Three of the children are Arab and have been born and raised in refugee camps in the Occupied Territories on the West Bank. Though divided by a journey of less than twenty minutes, it is as if they live in completely different worlds. By allowing the harsh realities of terrorism and the Intifada, of occupation and resistance, to be filtered through the experience of the children, “Promises” builds a compelling argument for multicultural and religious tolerance. The film climaxes with a meeting of the Palestinian and Israeli children which articulates the profound desire for peace on both sides. However, given the complexity of the politics of the conflict, “Promises” refuses to pretend that there are simple or straightforward answers to the co-existence of the two peoples. A coda which sees the filmmakers return to Jerusalem finds the children older, more cynical, and already involved in the hatred that arises from war: it is as if the failures of the peace negotiations are mirrored in the daily lives of the children themselves. “Promises” was nominated for an Academy Award for best feature documentary and it is a testament to the ethical and humanitarian commitments of its directors, Shapiro and Goldberg, that it allows for both emotional and intellectual engagement by the viewer, an engagement that never strikes one as manipulative. There is no false politicised “objectivity” assumed in “Promises” by the directors. Part of the film’s power arises from Goldberg and Shapiro desiring to assist the children on both sides of the conflict. It is their compassionate involvement that gives the film its grand tragic force. The video comes with explanatory notes and a study guide.

results.title: Prologue
results.creator_credit: Robin Spry, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A story focusing on the youth-rebellion movement of 1968, revolving around Jesse (John Robb) a young Montrealer who edits an underground newspaper. He and his female companion are joined by David (Gary Rader) a young draft dodger from the United States. In the choices they make, the two rival philosophies of dissenting youth become evident: militant protest or communal retreat. The film includes some of the bloody rioting in Chicago during the 1968 Democratic Convention. Also seen and heard in the film is anti-war and civil rights spokesman Abbie Hoffman. Other members of the Intellectual Left making brief appearances in Prologue include Allen Ginsberg, Jean Genet, John Kenneth Galbraith, and William S. Burroughs. Cast includes: Elaine Malus, Christopher Cordeaux, Peter Cullen, Frank Edwards, Henry Gamer, Robert Girolami and Victor Knight. Script, Sherwood Forest. Editing, Christopher Cordeaux. Music, Bill Brooks, Michael Malus and The Ventures. (Awards: London, Toronto, Colombo)

results.title: Mozzie
results.creator_credit: AFTRS, Jane Keneally and Dylan Yeo
results.brief_description: Spectacular animation about fluorocarbons, global warming and radical brain surgery. An evil entrepreneur discovers the real price of his actions. Combined live action and computer animation. Written, directed and animated by Dylan Yeo. Original format 35mm/colour.

results.title: Dusty hearts
results.creator_credit: AFTRS, Mariel Beros and Pauline Chan
results.brief_description: Sax Elthan is a hapless musician, a refugee from the inner city. Rejected by his girlfriend, he travels to the outback to look for work. One burning Wednesday he finds himself beside a highway, waiting for a lift, contemplating his future. It arrives in the shape of a beat-up Volkswagon with a wardrobe tied to the roof. A black comedy about one man’s destiny starring Geoff Morrell (Blue Heelers, Changi). Also features Tina Bursill.

results.title: Projection Privee = Private Projection
results.brief_description:
Denis, a young director who is still traumatised by the violent death of his young lover, decides to make a film with about this tragic episode. One of the highlights of this film is the insight it gives into the actual mechanics of filmmaking.

Credits: Director, Francois Leterrier ; writer, Francois Leterrier, Madeleine Chapsal, Bernard Revon ; photography, Jean Badal ; music, Serge Gainsbourg, Jean-Claude Vannier.
Cast: Francoise Fabian, Jean-Luc Bideau, Jane Birkin, Bulle Ogier, Jacques Weber.
